poem:
"An Unexpected Visit From the New World"

Buoyant apostle of Floridian rapture, 
alone you danced, 4,000 miles of wave and wit.
Stitched in sun-kissed hue, incessant in your departure,
Upon Eriskay's isle, your pilgrimage finds it: 
A rest between histories, a tale half whispered,
From Bonnie Charlie's ghost to whisky dreams, forever tethered.
A new mariner's song echoed, curious yet undisturbed.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It bust loose and went to Europe’: Florida buoy washes up in Scotland From Bonnie Prince Charlie’s ill-fated 1745 landing, to the shipwreck of a whisky-laden cargo freighter two centuries later that inspired a bestselling novel and blockbuster movie, the tiny Scottish island of Eriskay has a rich and outsized history of notable maritime events. Now, the arrival of a visitor from Florida following a 4,000-mile solo voyage across the Atlantic has added another curious". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
